etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Johnson (d. 1644), apothecary and soldier. From classical Latin sīmus having a flattened nose, (of nostrils) flattened, splayed (from ancient Greek σῑμός flat-nosed, (of the nose) snub, flat, bent upwards, uphill, hollow, concave, in Hellenistic Greek specifically with reference to the bottom of the liver, also denoting a kind of fish; of unknown origin) + -ous

definitions: Bending or curving inward; concave. Also (in later use chiefly): (of the nose) snub, flat.
